alignments.summary: Safeguards against platform coercion and state-level adversaries.
alignments.submission_title: Secure, Organic Community Formation on the Meta-layer
alignments.submission_overview: This submission proposes pathways for vulnerable and like-minded communities to discover one another, coordinate securely, and exchange value peer-to-peer without relying on centralized platforms. It includes recommendations for enhancing Desirable Properties to better protect these communities from deplatforming, surveillance, and identity compromise. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Bridge paths trace information lineage for stronger knowledge provenance.
alignments.submission_title: Bridges, Synaptic Web, and Universal Maps: Toward a Cognitive Meta-layer
alignments.submission_overview: This multi-part proposal outlines an architectural evolution of the web through three interconnected primitives: 1) Bridges as first-class web infrastructure, 2) The Synaptic Web as an adaptive, evolving collective intelligence, and 3) Universal knowledge maps for navigation, learning, and sensemaking. Together, these ideas transform the Meta-layer into a dynamic scaffold for contextual intelligence, verifiable information, and community co-creation. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Recommends mandatory embedded metadata and tamper-evident signing for AI outputs.
alignments.submission_title: Walking the Narrow Path: Reinforcing AI Governance, Containment, and Trust in the Meta-layer
alignments.submission_overview: This submission draws from Tristan Harris’s 2025 TED talk to underscore the urgency of reinforcing the Meta-layer’s AI-related Desirable Properties. It highlights the existential risks posed by unregulated AI systems and argues for clear implementation protocols in governance, containment, and transparency. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Emphasizes the value of content-addressable storage (e.g., IPFS) in ensuring provenance and verifiability.
alignments.submission_title: Save As to Web3: A UX Gateway to Decentralized Storage
alignments.submission_overview: This proposal upgrades the familiar 'save as...' functionality into a Web3-native interaction—allowing users to save files directly to decentralized cloud storage such as IPFS. By embedding decentralized storage options into user interfaces, this approach enables user agency and sovereignty without requiring technical knowledge. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Applies strong encryption and user-owned identity to protect provenance and security.
alignments.submission_title: Security Protocols and Ethical Safeguards in the Lyra System
alignments.submission_overview: This submission distills the architecture and protective mechanisms of the Lyra System—a privacy-centric, emotionally intelligent interface—focusing on its multi-layered approach to identity security, data sovereignty, ethical data handling, and emotional consent. Lyra integrates decentralized identity protocols, local storage autonomy, soulbound emotional markers, and open governance to establish a radically secure and self-protective environment. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3

alignments.summary: Proposes blockchain-based timestamping and digital signatures to secure reports.
alignments.submission_title: Enhancing Whistleblower Protection within the Meta-Layer
alignments.submission_overview: This submission draws upon established frameworks from WPAC (2015) and Security.org to propose enhancements to whistleblower systems in alignment with the Meta-Layer's Desirable Properties. It emphasizes secure, anonymized federated authentication, user-controlled data sovereignty, interoperable and simplified reporting interfaces, and system-wide transparency and security protocols. These systems are essential to protect whistleblowers from retaliation and to ensure credibility, participation, and systemic accountability. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Ensures digital artifacts retain cryptographic marks, signature chains, and verifiable metadata as they propagate.
alignments.submission_title: Name Chain–Anchored Digital Artifacts with Interoperable Authentication Marks
alignments.submission_overview: This pattern enables any digital object—text, credential, file, token—to carry a human-readable name (e.g., @name/object) and a verifiable, interoperable mark of authentication. These objects can travel across the open web while retaining provenance, trust context, and actionable semantics. The system allows for persistent identity, cross-platform verification, and composability of trustable content, providing a semantic envelope for use in overlays, presence layers, or public ledgers. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3. This submission was inspired by a conversation with Jaime Schwartz about his name chain and provenance tech.

alignments.summary: Every piece of data is cryptographically signed, allowing recipients to verify authorship and detect tampering.
alignments.submission_title: Towards Decentralized Applications: Rethinking Control Power and Data Exchange in Named-Data Networking
alignments.submission_overview: This submission presents a comprehensive framework and prototype for decentralized applications built on Named-Data Networking (NDN), aimed at resolving centralization in control power over user data, identity, and communications. Through the design, implementation, and evaluation of "NDN Workspace," the work demonstrates how semantic naming, data-centric security, and distributed data synchronization can enable direct, secure, and serverless peer-to-peer collaboration. The study also contributes critical insights into naming schemes, trust schema enforcement, and the broader ecosystem architecture required to support real-time collaborative applications outside the cloud paradigm. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Ensures transparency applies to AI as much as human interactions in high-trust networks.
alignments.submission_title: Governance for Advanced Non-Human Agents and AI Systems
alignments.submission_overview: Based on Dr. Paul John Werbos's Saving the World and New Jerusalem posts, this submission proposes clarifications and extensions to numerous Desirable Properties to account for the governance, authentication, and accountability of advanced non-human agents and AI systems, including those that may operate in physical or hybrid embodiments, participate in economic systems, or manage critical infrastructure. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Ensures digital provenance by embedding AI-origin metadata, allowing verification of content origin and authenticity.
alignments.submission_overview: This submission proposes a requirement that generative AI applications hosted on websites embed clear, machine-readable metadata in all digital artifacts they create—including podcasts, audio, video, images, and text—indicating that the content was generated by AI. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3

alignments.summary: Supports efforts to prevent data misuse by surfacing insecure or opaque data flows.
alignments.submission_title: AI-Augmented Data Visibility for Safer Web Experiences
alignments.submission_overview: This submission proposes an AI-augmented tool (e.g., a browser extension or embedded prototype) that transparently reveals what data is being collected and tracked during web interactions. It aims to equip users with actionable insight into data flows and help mitigate exploitative ad-based surveillance. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Uses cryptographic attestations for data integrity and source verification.
alignments.submission_title: Chromium Reputation Provider Framework: A Decentralized Reputation Layer for the Web
alignments.submission_overview: This draft proposal from the Chromium team outlines a browser-native framework enabling users to install, manage, and utilize multiple independent reputation providers. It envisions a decentralized ecosystem for reputational signals, facilitating both positive and negative assessments of websites and content. This approach prioritizes user choice, system resilience, and reputational pluralism over centralized moderation or gatekeeping by browser vendors. It aims to replicate the utility of walled-garden trust systems (e.g., Amazon reviews) while retaining the open and user-controlled nature of the web. The framework proposes multiple technical mechanisms for secure and privacy-respecting attestations, enabling scalable and nuanced integration of reputational data into browsing experiences. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Provides semantic annotation and cryptographic integrity verification across systems.
alignments.submission_title: Enabling Machine-Readable Meaning through the Semantic Web
alignments.submission_overview: This submission revisits the seminal 2001 vision of the Semantic Web, proposing its relevance and expanded applicability to modern decentralized meta-systems. It explores how the foundational architecture of the Semantic Web—built on distributed knowledge representation, interoperable ontologies, and machine-readable logic—prefigures the infrastructure needed for scalable, composable, and user-aligned digital environments. The submission identifies alignment with multiple Desirable Properties, especially regarding knowledge portability, participatory governance, and ethical agentic systems. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Addresses the real-world dangers of deepfakes and fake AI influencers used for scams.
alignments.submission_title: The Algorithmic Collapse: Reclaiming Humanity in the Age of AI Slop
alignments.submission_overview: This submission critiques the current trajectory of internet culture, shaped by a deluge of AI-generated content that mimics human creativity without its soul. It raises alarms about the degradation of trust, the erosion of digital authenticity, and the weaponization of engagement algorithms. It also highlights the need for systemic reevaluation: how we value creative labor, what constitutes "real" content, and the risks of unchecked AI proliferation in social, artistic, and journalistic domains. The human internet is not dead—but it's under siege. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
